segments.text: Honey, I was going to write you a letter and put it in with these tapes, and then I thought, well, I might as well talk to you for a while on this other tape instead of writing a letter.
This is November the 28th, Thursday, November the 28th, and Phyllis has the parcels ready to ship, the Christmas parcels ready to ship to Toronto.
Toronto and Janie and Calgary, I presume. No, Calgary, they'll be down here. They'll pick theirs up here.
Anyway, everything's going fine here. We've got nice weather now the last three or four days.
I've been doing some work on my water softener. The valve shut off. The valve on the water line wouldn't shut off anymore. It was all corroded.
And the...
The one going into the pan on the humidifier has been leaking, and I couldn't get it adjusted, so I'm putting in a new valve, a new float valve.
Believe it or not, the little plastic thing, $12.75.
And I don't know how long it'll last, but the other one lasts about five, six years, and then the orifice goes on them,
and you can put a new...
a new rubber gasket in it, and it won't shut the water off.
And I have to run around and pick up the parts fast. You've got to go here, and you've got to go there.
One guy has one thing, and the next guy has the other thing.
Between the two shopping malls here, I've been able to gather up the stuff I need.
What else am I doing? Yeah, I'm going to put a...
a plastic, stiff plastic cover in front of the fireplace.
I've done some testing. I put cardboard in there back when it was so cold.
What a difference it made in this family room.
You can't imagine the cold air that came out through that fireplace.
It's not a draft. It's just a continuous cold coming in.
I put a cardboard in there, and it shut it all off tight, and you could sit in here, and...
when it was, you know, 10, 15 below zero, and your feet were nice and warm.
Or before that, you'd sit in here, and your feet were always cold.
I talked to George the other day.
He phoned me to tell me that he had been to the annual meeting of the Elks,
where they give out their pins for the year.
Next year, I'm up for my 45th year as an Elk.
Georgia, it has his...
coming into his 50th in a year or so.
He's keeping fine. Sounds good.
Said he had been talking to you guys.
I better check on this sheet. It's taping properly.
Yeah, it seemed to be taping, so all I have to do is lay back in the lazy boy here and talk.
If I can think of what to say, it's...
You know, unless you have some special topic to talk on, it's pretty hard to keep on a continuous conversation.
I'm getting quite a kick out of all the...
bad news.
You never hear anything good on TV. It's always bad.
Poor Regan, he's into it up to his knees.
And I don't think our boys in Ottawa are much better.
They're trying to patch up here and patch up there to make it look good, but oh boy.
The old debt keeps on piling up, piling up.
Sinclair Stevens is having a hell of a time.
I laugh at, when we're at the coffee row, I say,
they shouldn't be so hard on that guy.
You know, I shook hands with him about 20 years ago.
He's a pretty nice fella.
You probably don't know that.
It was at the time that I was a signer for the Western Bank of Canada,
that Stevens and Klein were going to start up.
And they were down here.
And had a meeting in the Saskatchewan Hotel.
And all of us that were signers for it were invited there,
you know, just to hear them talk and ask questions.
In the end, they never started the bank.
They got squabbling amongst themselves who was going to control it.
And that's where it stopped.
But right now, it seems that Stevens has got himself in plenty.
Plenty of a mess.
If you can go by what you see and hear on TV,
it looks pretty rotten.
And that both him and his wife are just sitting there
telling one thing after the other,
and deny, deny, deny.
The fella that loaned her, what, $2.6 million,
without knowing who she was.
I think he was lying a little bit, too.
However, that's all past.
Let her go.
Right today on the news, it came over.
You talk about bad news.
The news, or this morning I heard,
that there was a policeman in Calgary
that had robbed 20, or had staged 20 bank holdups
in Calgary in the last couple of years.
He's a policeman, 33 years old,
father of a family of seven,
and a very unassuming guy.
And I don't know how they got suspicious,
but I guess they followed him after hours or something
and caught him in the act
and tagged 20 robberies after him.
Whether he was responsible for all of them, I don't know.
That's some more bad news.
The First Minister's meeting in Vancouver,
I listened to it for nine hours one day,
and they all did a magnificent job presenting their case.
But each one ended up the next day then holding his ad out,
give us some money, give us some money,
we need this, we need money to do that.
Well, Rudy says, God, fellas, I'm trying to hold the line.
He says, there's got to be an end to handouts.
However, some way, somehow, they'll keep it going,
keep on rolling.
Then, oh yeah, I was talking to Hugo the other day,
stopped in there for coffee in the morning
when I was out for a walk.
He's keeping fine.
Oh, he's mad at the government.
He did all a bunch of things.
Then he said he was in Vancouver trying to...
negotiate a deal for some of these...
one of these machines that makes steel bins.
And it was some complicated deal that he had a chance
to buy $15,000 worth of steel for $9,000,
but he couldn't find anybody that needed a bin.
So I guess that's put on the back burner.
Other than that, he didn't have anything to say.
Not any.
And the farmers here are suffering.
Of course, they holler like hell.
It always was that way.
Farming was always a tough deal in Saskatchewan.
My God.
Remember when I was home on the farm,
the years that you went through the farm,
they got enough to pull you through.
But Dad never asked for anything.
We never got five cents from the government.
Dad worked for 17 years,
and he never went to the municipality or anybody
to get seed or help or anything.
He always stayed on top of the pile.
Of course, he had a lot of manpower around there to help.
I suppose that didn't hurt any.
Although there were other families around there
that were just as big a family as we had
that never made it through at all.
After five, six years, they'd fold up
and head back to the States where they came from.
That's the last you'd hear of them.
But the farmers, well, sure,
they're not going to make it big.
Those that bought land at $400, $500, $600 an acre,
they're in trouble.
There's no question about it.
You can't pay them for land
and then sell wheat for $2.50 or $3.00 a bushel.
Right now, a lot of this grain,
where they have the big heavy crop,
particularly in the Regina area here,
if they didn't get it off before the rain,
it's going to go for about $3.00, $4.00, $5.00 or feet,
and they only get a couple dollars a bushel for it.
Well, that doesn't pound up very fast.
Those that got theirs off first,
I guess they get about better than $3.00 a bushel.
But their quota is only 2.9 bushels to the acre,
so they can only sell enough to pay the gas bill,
and that's about all.
The banker and the implement company will have to wait.
Yesterday, Don Horstman, one of my rummy friends,
picked me up.
We went out for coffee.
The rummy games haven't been going on for about three months now.
Bill Harkson, one of the stable, steady guys,
he's got vision problems the same as I have.
We're both about equal visually.
He's been in the hospital for almost three months now.
He's 81 years old, and he just had a stomach operation,
and his kidneys are gone.
He's in a hell of a shape.
He told me a month ago, he said,
I'll never get out of here.
And he could be right,
but he's in pretty bad shape.
Keep pouring blood into him and keep him going.
I'm going up to see him this afternoon.
He's been in intensive care.
I haven't seen him now for about eight days.
Whoop.
And have a chat with him.
It's hard to visit with a guy,
and he's been laying in bed like that.
You know, they lose interest.
He doesn't have TV or radio,
and they sort of lose interest in what's going on
in the outside world.
And what else did I see?
Oh, I guess we told you that Alan Aiken,
Mac's wife, passed away.
Yes, we told you that.
And I was talking to Ethel.
At that time, I phoned Ethel to let her know about it.
She's keeping fine up in Edgar.
I'll give her an announcement.
And Jimmy Warren's getting married,
he's, you know, on the 6th of December,
you'll probably have an announcement.
He wasn't sending out invitations.
He said, we didn't expect you guys to come that far.
It's been an afternoon at a wedding.
And he did the same with us.
He said, I don't expect you people to come up.
And he said, it's a lot of fuss for us.
And this time of the year and the weather is so uncertain, I don't think that Wally
and Willa are going up.
If anything, Wally may go, but Willa, she's settled down there and seems to be feeling
pretty good since she got back down there.
She was not in very good shape the last time she was up here, which was just before the
end of October.
Not herself at all.
She's been and I'm interested in things.
Hard to converse with.
But now, we talked around the phone the other night on Wally's birthday, which was on the
17th of November.
She sounded really good.
She said she's feeling good, too.
And oh, yeah, the big city of Albright got on the news the night before last.
The guy that delivers mail from here down to Weyburn and all the towns along the line
to Estevan and I don't know how far beyond.
But when he's at Albright about 5 o'clock in the morning, I guess he must have a key
to put the mail bags in the post office.
And two or three guys jumped him to come into the post office and tied him up and took his
truck, a load of mail, and went about nine miles north of Albright out into a field.
And he said, you know what?
We're going to open up all the mail bags and searching.
I guess they got a bunch of money that was to go up to the co-op or credit unit in Estevan.
And they smashed the headlights on the truck, I don't know why, and let it stand out in
the field.
Somebody saw it, I guess, and went out there and see what was happening and caught out
it was the mail truck.
They have no clue of ever, excepting from the driver, who said that he thought it was
three guys that jumped him and blindfolded him and tied him up and put a rope around
his neck to start with.
He could be implicated in a thing, too.
You never know.
Either way, that's the way it goes.
The snow is all gone here, excepting on the north side of the building, just a little.
The backyard, maybe two inches.
Well, the streets are icy.
The sidewalks are icy.
It didn't all melt.
It didn't totally disappear.
It just got out here and sort of melted a little during the day.
The sun don't get very high these days.
My god, I just said to fellas the other day, I said, it's going to have to keep working
pretty hard to stay above the horizon by the twenty-first of December, the way it gets
up in the morning at nine o'clock, it's just barely showing up at nine o'clock in the morning.
I don't know how it is with you fellas here farther south.
Yeah, you'd see quite a bit more of it than you do here.
The days would be longer.
Oh, I got my reading machine. Boy, I can really read the fine print with it. When I was installing
these parts on the water softener, the print is so fine, you know, and I put it under there
and I could pull it up and I could read just as plain as anything. So I opened the mail
today and the mail came in. I opened the letters. I was able to read the letters and see what
was in them. So I'll have that to keep me busy. I won't be spending so much time on
the tape. During the day, I don't pay any attention to TV, excepting I get an hour of
news at noon, and then I don't bother the TV again until half past five. I turn it on
for the news from Yorkton, and at six o'clock the China news comes on. So I watch it about
an hour.
And then I watch all the sports. Football. I'm still enjoying my football. It's not much
better on TV than it is at the game, because you see all the replays. I'm just going to
stop for a minute. I have to stop and clear my throat for a little while. When I talk
very much, my voice gets foggy, because I don't talk that much. You're out here, and
Phyllis and I are alone. You don't do much talking.
So when you get a chance to talk, you get a chance to talk.
For 10, 50 minutes straight, your voice starts to get foggy right away. I noticed that yesterday
when I was up at Euplos. I sat there for half an hour and talking, and my voice almost totally
faltered by the time I left there. And I think it's just from lack of exercise. I'll have
to do some taping to myself, and then play them back and erase them, and then tape them
over again.
oh yeah i'm sending these tapes to you that's that's the second version of my life's history
uh i i wasn't happy with the first one it was badly taped
anyway jane and joe they've got the first version of it and then i took and i run that over and
and we ended the whole thing and that's what you're getting now and uh when danny gets a
a tape deck i'll send him one i'll send him a copy to him in the meantime he can listen to yours
there's four hours of taping and uh you'll find some of it interesting some of it's sort of
monotonous berlin give me the dickens he said you talked for four hours and you never mentioned one
thing about your family i said this was my life that i was talking about my working life not by
not my family
or the social side of my life it's my working life that i was taping it and i'm sure that
good and dan will get quite a bit out of it having both worked for the company and has
some notion of what it's all about what goes on out there and uh yeah what else
oh yeah at ellen's funeral lyle and family were down there
lyle's still pretty pretty hefty
still working i don't want time that he's going to take a fast
early retirement but i guess he's still able to carry on i don't know what's going to happen to
the dome they're still hanging on pushing the car in the heaven dragging up behind them whichever
every once in a while you hear something that says
they're in trouble
of him refinancing and constantly refinancing but for this as long as
i keep going he's got a job and having heard from
melton i wrote him a long letter about oh about the end of
august and he still hasn't
lengthly received as there it is a letter from ken and peggy williams they're heading south

for palm springs for four months so norm if you want to find out an important density of covid appliances you can do that later on the cover story but reasoning underneath theпарade is so tough to술 the farmyard's where the lgbt soient hurtulltüm
something about Palm Springs, you can give them a call someday. All they do is
golf. They get a place right by the golf course, and I guess they, they have a golf,
what do you call it, membership for the four months of there, and they're out in the golf
course every day. I guess they get tired in D.C., they can golf all winter, but it's
pretty wet. They have to put on rubber boots, but they, the Oregon golfers still go out
and bat that ball around, even if it is wet. On December the 9th, I just got a letter today,
Central Line Contractors, that's the one that I helped organize. I was the first president
of the Central Line Contractors of Saskatchewan. They're having a, whatever, hospitality hour
in the Hotel Saskatchewan in December.
So that'll be an evening out for me, see and hear what's going on. Power business, I don't
hear much. It's all very quiet. Well, Bud Waltz dropped in yesterday. He's working in
this area, and he dropped in for a cup of coffee. He's 57 years old. He said, I can't
wait till I'm 60. I want to get out, he said, retire at 60. It's getting tougher every day,
the older you get. He's in the gas department now to get down on your knees and work on,
and these gas furnaces isn't any joke. I've seen them come into my place here, and if
the guys kid over here in crowded quarters, and they have to get down on your knees, it's
hard work. I haven't been off the shop. I told you that Ruttnay lumber burnt down. Just
the office portion of it burned up, and they knocked all the rest of it down. There's nothing
but a barrel out there now.
We had some sad news the day before yesterday. Just said that Clarence Heard and his wife,
Agnes, died suddenly. This was in the obituaries. Died suddenly on November the 20th, at a private
funeral. He has three daughters, one in Hawaii, one in White Rock, B.C., and one in Winnipeg,
at a private funeral.
And then it comes out that his wife, Agnes, died suddenly.
And his wife had Alzheimer's and arthritis very badly. He carried her out to the garage.
Now, this is a story we get when there's two of them. Carried her out to the garage and
put her in the back seat of the car, and he got in the front seat and started the motor
up, and that was it. I don't know how long it would take you to get gas out in the garage.
He would only have a single garage.
Probably wouldn't take very long. So Clarence put an end to it. He was about seventy-four
or five years old. And you know who he was. He run the Rutley Lumber across the corner
from me, and I had known him for twenty years. Then I was in business there, and of course
another twenty since. That's why I've known him for about forty years now. Real nice type
of a guy. Been quite a nicer man. Good living.
And I guess the reason he went with her, they were a very close couple. Throughout
the years, he was quite a home man, and I guess he couldn't take it anymore. And Gordon
South died. I think Danny will have that in a letter that we will have.
He can't sell much of it. Well, I guess he can if he's got a quota of two point five
nine bushels per acre. And that's for every cultivated acre you have, so he could sell
maybe most of his wheat with the amount of acres he has cultivated between him and his
boys. They work in one big operation. And he said he took in last year, he took in forty-five
hundred dollars from oil, and he doesn't own an oil well. Forty-five thousand dollars.
That was in surface rights that pay you forty-five hundred dollars.
Forty-five hundred dollars a well now. And when they drill a well, I think they give
you five or six thousand for the initial year. And then he had two or three dugouts, and
he's selling water. Sells a thousand dollars worth of water to drill a well. So he said,
I took in forty-five thousand dollars from oil, and don't own an oil well. He has just
the surface rights as well.
So that helped him a little bit. He's had a tough, tough, tough time. He was expanding,
and a big family, and wanted to keep the boys on the farm. He had a family of thirteen,
you know, same as we had, and we lived on that same farm. And they're all pretty well
growing up, you know. The youngest one may be twelve, thirteen years old.
Yeah.
And when I was that age, I was doing a man's work around the farm. Anything from driving
an outfit in the fields to, you know, hauling manure, feeding the cows, milking the cows,
feeding the hogs. Yeah, you worked ten, twelve hours a day in the man's house. Unless you
were at school, you got away from some of the pens.
I think I told Danny about hunting. I haven't heard a word about hunting for two years now,
you know. Except Kevin Murphy, I know, goes out for a deer every year. But I never see
him. I hear this from a friend of his, but I don't see him up at the Elks. But they're
going out around East End for mule deer. And this fellow goes with Kevin. And the old Murphy,
oldest Murphy girl had her second baby just the other day. They got two babies in about
one year.
I think Phyllis had her, you know, twelve, thirteen months or something. And the other
one, Patsy, she's working as a nurse. She had a sick spell a while back. She wasn't
sure what to do. But I see her car is a little now, so I guess she's back to work. Nothing
else. Chains in the neighborhood. Never see the Cernyks. I saw Kenny and missed the Cernyks
about six weeks ago. I was out for a walk.
I went down Sunset, and Kenny was out doing something to his car. And I went over and
talked to him. And I talked to him quite a while before. I thought it was Wayne that
had talked to him quite a while before. Oh, I said, you're Kenny. And he said, yeah. He
said, I didn't think you recognized me. That poor-eyesighted thing. Mr. Cernyk happened
to come out to ask Kenny something about his thing. Had a few words with him. The brown
boys haven't heard a thing for over a year now, maybe a year and a half. But Damien dropped
in here one day, and I wasn't home when he visited the Philistines. But I understand
he's the head maitre d' at golf, unless he's changed in the last couple of months.
Started climbing up the ladder in a hurry. I can't see him. I can't create a Chinese
run. Well, I guess he must have a way to get up the ladder. I'm running. I'm not talking
very fast. I might as well keep this thing going, because you have to run it to the end
anyway to get back to Cape Horn. So I can't think of anything else to say. Lots to say.
Yeah, you know, the girls. Linda phoned me the other night, wanted to know how to make
dough for apple pie. No crust. She was having problems couldn't get it to stick together.
I couldn't believe it. At her age, she didn't know how to make a pie crust. I almost told
her, and she did all the motions, but it was over the telephone, so I don't know if Linda
discussed how you had to work it and everything. But both of them, we didn't hear any more
about that anyway. Pension checks came in. I've got to go down and put them in the bank
to pay my bills. Those came in about four or five days before the end of the month.
Thank goodness. It's upstairs getting ready now, so. But the time is, it's going on to
two o'clock, yeah. It's going on to two o'clock soon. Shortly we'll be pulling out. And I
don't know. I've been feeling good. I walked, yesterday I walked 15 blocks. Yesterday morning
when I left for, walked down to Canadian Tire. No, first I walked, yeah, I walked for about
the bus to look for coffee. By the time I get in for coffee, I, I walk up to the Optimist
Club. That's four blocks. I catch the bus. And then the time I get in for coffee, that's
six blocks. Then I count another bus and went down to Canadian Tire, and then I went up
to see Hugo and Kelly at coffee there. Got home, I figured out I had walked 15 blocks.
And it didn't bother me a bit. Well, today I walked just about the same. I walked down
to Canadian Tire and back again.
That amounts to about 14 blocks. My, my legs are, are standing up good. In fact, I get
some muscles that are hardening up, but they're always so flabby. Now they're starting to get
some muscles. I'm keeping my weight up. I'm probably up a couple pounds right now, the
way my pants impact. I can't see the scales, so they're not much of a deal with me going
in and looking like this. That's why I called Phyllis there to tell me how much I could
weigh, and I think she'd probably not tell me the truth, but she always tells me I should
put on more weight. And I said, yeah, then I have to go out and buy new clothes, or else
get them readjusted or on the waistband. So I said, I'm heavy enough. When Bud Waltz saw
me yesterday, he was here when I came in for coffee, and he looked at me and said, boy,
you could put on, paint some of Phyllis's excess weight and put her on you, and you'd
look better, and she'd look better. I don't know how Phyllis liked this, but she didn't
say anything. She looked sharp for that thing. If I put on any weight and something like
that on the waistband, there's no place I'd own it. It's time to slack up at the breakfast
table or the supper table, whichever. We're all sitting down for a great cup on Sunday.
I'm afraid that Hamilton will have trouble with that. It's pretty solid up there. God
bless him.
Well, I was standing there as a quarterback with the diamond on top of the moon running
with the ball. They asked Parker the last game, don't you worry about him when he runs
like that? He said, that's the way he wants to play it. Instead of running away, just
let him go. So far so good. But Hamilton played one hell of a game against Joppa last
Sunday. But the most impossible thing happened. I was up there the other night in Miami. It
wiping the jets out. Three points to, what, forty-five?
And I kept on going, marking them up and marking them up.
Well, I'm about halfway through this tape I'm running,
put it on flash forward and run it to the end,
and then throw it in the box and give them an edge.
When you play this tape, when you play the fake tape over,
when you run it, you have Danny there,
and I'm sure with the two of you, you'll get more out of it,
and you'll be able to add some comments about this and about that.
I often lay back and think now that some of the things that happened
in the course of my lifetime, it's hard to explain to somebody
that hasn't been there and done the same thing.
And...
My thrashing days, that don't mean anything to you fellas.
That was the big harvest time, you know,
and that's when everything happened.
And it was really something for a young fellow like me
to go through, anyway, when I was nineteen years old
and started running a thrashing machine.
And it was always the stories that go around,
that this guy never, the machine never stops,
or that guy, he's stopping half the time.
So if you're a good operator, everybody in the country knew.
There's no question about that.
As I said when I was in South Dakota,
I always separated grain clean.
When it started coming in the elevators,
the elevator men couldn't believe that the grain
could come that clean out of a thrashing machine.
To me, it's just the only way you do it,
is not to keep working at it until you've got everything set.
That's the way it came out then.
But you think, have a notebook.
A notebook will do a good job of taking notes
about this and about that.
I can give you the details.
Merlin said, how can you remember back 50 years?
Oh, I can remember in detail things that happened
40, 50 years ago, I said.
And remember the dates and everything, no problem.
That's what I had for breakfast,
and supper last night, and I had for things like
hell with him.
Do you remember what I ate for supper last night?
That's part of growing old.
Oh yeah, I had a letter from Cascade, Iowa,
from the cousins that were up here this summer.
And they mentioned about Uncle Hiller,
that was my mother's youngest brother,
who is still living at 104 years of age.
He fell last spring and cracked his hip,
but he's back up walking again.
His mind, I guess, is sort of spraying
a bit, but she said, I had put a message
in the letter to her, for her dad,
and she read it out to him, but she said
he couldn't remember much about the ache
excepting Laurie, who left the oldest brother.
He and Laurie were just about the same age.
So his memory must be failing a bit,
which one can expect.
But he's remarkable.
He was never a strong man.
He was always a kind of a frail looking man.
I remember back in 1925,
when I first met him,
he had a crippled arm,
one hooked arm.
The elbow was stiffened.
He used that one.
He could tip.
He was a good drinker.
He could tip a drink with it.
I looked him down.
He was mad.
Never weighed over 140, 145 pounds.
And all the rest of the Smiths
was a big, huge fellow,
up to 250 pounds.
So I wish you all
including you, Linda,
and all the kids
a very, very Merry Christmas
and a Happy New Year.
We'd like to be talking to you at that time
to say over and out.
Just now I was wondering what all that noise was
and I find out I had the microphone in my hand
and as the cord bends a little bit
there's all that clicking and whatnot.
So I'll know better the next time
I'll set the mic down and talk into it.
